Line 1: Line 1: â
[[Image:NagHammadi 1.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Texts of the [[Nag Hammadi library]]]]
 
{{Bible related}}
{{Bible related}}
The '''New Testament apocrypha''' are a number of writings by [[Early Christianity|early Christians]] that claim to be accounts of [[Jesus]] and his teachings, the nature of [[God]], or the teachings of his apostles and of their lives. These writings often have links with books regarded as "canonical". Not every branch of the Christian church agrees on which writings should be regarded as "[[wikt:canonical|canonical]]" and which are "[[wikt:apocryphal|apocryphal]]" (See, for example, the [[Gospel according to the Hebrews]]).
The '''New Testament apocrypha''' are a number of writings by [[Early Christianity|early Christians]] that claim to be accounts of [[Jesus]] and his teachings, the nature of [[God]], or the teachings of his apostles and of their lives. These writings often have links with books regarded as "canonical". Not every branch of the Christian church agrees on which writings should be regarded as "[[wikt:canonical|canonical]]" and which are "[[wikt:apocryphal|apocryphal]]" (See, for example, the [[Gospel according to the Hebrews]]).
